citation.article-title: Cellulomonas persica sp. nov. and Cellulomonas iranensis sp. nov., mesophilic cellulose-degrading bacteria isolated from forest soils.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Cellulomonas persica sp. nov.
Cellulomonas persica (per'si.ca. L. fem. adj. Persica Persian, from Persia, classical name of Iran, where the organism was isolated)
Irregular, straight or slightly curved rods 0.6x2.0- 4.0 μm, which occasionally exhibit typical coryneform branching.
Cells are motile, with one to four peritrichous flagella.
Colonies are light yellow, ca. 1 mm in diameter, circular, convex and glossy.
Additional characteristics that differentiate this species include the ability to produce acid from dextrin and the inability to utilize D-ribose or raffinose.
Starch and gelatin are hydrolysed, the latter weakly.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite ; DNase produced.
Urea hydrolysed as N source in cellulose fermentation.
Cell wall is of the L-Orn-D-Asp type and contains the sugars rhamnose, glucosamine and minor amounts of mannose.
Source of the isolate is forest humus soil located under walnut, fig, hornbeam, mimosa and box trees in Ramsar Forest, 1.6 kmsouth of Ramsar, Iran, along the border of the Caspian Sea.
Type strain IT has been deposited as ATCC 700642T.
